_prev_prog_3.Description:
The Baze Chemical Palestine Plant consists of a single process covered under both OSHA PSM (29 CFR 1910.110) and EPA CAPP/RMP (40 CFR 68).



The Prevention Program at the Palestine Plant is based on satisfying the requirements of OSHA regulation for Process Safety Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals, as defined in 29 CFR 1910.119 and 40 CFR 68.  The program contains the following individual procedural elements:



PAL-PSM-001, Employee Participation, which address 40 CFR 68.83

PAL-PSM-002, Process Safety Information, which address 40 CFR 68.65

PAL-PSM-003, Process Hazard Analysis, which address 40 CFR 68.67

PAL-PSM-004, Operating Procedures, which address 40 CFR 68.69

PAL-PSM-005, Training, which address 40 CFR 68.71

PAL-PSM-006, Contractors, which address 40 CFR 68.87

PAL-PSM-007, Pre-Startup Safety Review, which address 40 CFR 68.77

PAL-PSM-008, Mechanical Integrity, which address 40 CFR 68.73

PAL-PSM-009, Hot Work, which address 40 CFR 68.85

PAL-PSM-010, Management of Change, which address 40 CFR 68.75

PAL-PSM-011, Incident Investigation, which address 40 CFR 68.81

PAL-PSM-012, Emergency Planning and Response, which address 40 CFR 68.95

PAL-PSM-013, Compliance Audits, which address 40 CFR 68.79

PAL-PSM-014, Trade Secrets, which is not required under 40 CFR 68.



The entire program was last revised and issued on 10 August 2015.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES



At Baze Chemical safety is our top concern.  In our manufacturing facilities we take special measures to ensure the safety of all involved.  



The policy on chemical safety at the Palestine Plant is to prevent the release of chemicals through high standards of design and operation, and to provide measures to mitigate releases should they occur.   Baze Chemical is committed to operating and maintaining the facility in a safe and responsible manner and has the goal of no accidents or injuries.



FACILITY AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES 



The Palestine Plant is an ethoxylation facility that produces a range of specialty surfactants for use predominantly in the oil and gas industry.  The process of ethoxylation involves reacting ethylene oxide with various common chemicals, such as fatty alcohols and phenols, to produce a variety of products. 



The plant can also use propylene oxide instead of (or as well as) ethylene oxide in a similar process known as "propoxylation".  



Regulated materials at the facility are ethylene oxide (up to 375,500 lb, or 49,000 gallons) and propylene oxide (up to 45,650 lb, or 6,600 gallons).  The other raw materials used in the process as well as the products are not regulated.  Both ethylene oxide (EO) and propylene oxide (PO) are stored in pressurized horizontal storage vessels equipped with external cooling facilities.



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM 



The facility complies with the OSHA PSM rules as defined in 29 CFR 1910.119 and Program 3 requirements under EPA CAPP rules as defined in 40 CFR 68.



Specific design features and operating practices at the facility relevant to the control of ethylene oxide and propylene oxide are:



- Purging with nitrogen after each transfer operation to prevent stagnant EO or PO liquid being present in piping.

- Facilities and procedure to regularly circulate the contents of the EO storage tanks, in accordance with recognize

d and generally accepted good engineering practices for the storage of EO.  Circulation of tank contents controls the potential for polymerization of EO.

- Facilities and procedures to cool the contents of the EO and PO storage tanks, using chilled water.  The design of the cooling system eliminates the potential for cross-contamination between either material and the chilled water.

- The provision of a scrubber system to remove trace vapors of EO or PO from vent discharges.

- Dual independent transmitters on each storage tank to warn of high or low level, high or low pressure, and high temperature.

- Padding of EO storage tanks with nitrogen to maintain the vapor space in the non-decomposable range.

- Automatic shutdown of EO and PO tanks on low motor power and on high pump casing temperature, so that pumps cannot be run "dead headed".

- Automatic shutdown of EO or PO injection to the reactors based on any one of the following reactor conditions: high temperature; high pressure; high level; lower stirrer power (which may indicate loss of stirring/agitation).

- Remote shutdown of EO rail car unloading liquid line.

- Remote shutdown of EO or PO tank liquid transfer.

- All penetration for liquid and vapor lines to the EO and PO tanks are via top entry, thereby eliminating nozzles below the liquid level.

- Secondary containment around the EO and PO storage tanks, sized for at least 110% of the largest inventory.

- Passive fire protection of the EO and PO storage tanks to minimize the heat input to the tanks during a fire and avoid conditions that could lead to a BLEVE (boiling liquid expanding vapor explosion).

- Water deluge system over the EO / PO storage tanks to suppress vapor dispersion of accidental spills.

- Operating philosophy that requires a minimum of two operators to be present during each activity involving transfer of EO or PO.



FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY 



The Palestine Plant is a new facility that has not yet commenced beneficial operat

ion and has had no accidents to report.



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM 



The emergency response program for the Palestine Plant is based on the premise of minimal active intervention by plant personnel, other than remove shutdown of equipment, isolation of inventory, and activation of fixed vapor mitigation water deluge system.  The program addresses all the requirement of OSHA regulations for emergency action plans (per 29 CFR 1910.38).



Coordination with local emergency responders is ongoing.  Baze Chemical has met hosted meetings at the plant with Scott Parkhurst, Emergency Management Coordinator for the City of Palestine, and Alan Wilcher, Palestine Fire Chief, to discuss possible emergency conditions at the plant.  Information on RMP worst credible scenario and alternative scenarios have been provided, together with a copy of the site's Emergency Response Plan.  The Palestine emergency services will act as "first responders" in the event of an emergency at the site.  Discussions with response agencies and familiarization of first responders with the facility are ongoing.



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



The Palestine Plant is a new facility built to high standards.  While there are no specific planned changes, the facility will be managed in accordance with established process safety and environmental protection procedures.  During the initial 1-2 years of operation it is anticipated that employees may identify one or more opportunities to improve safety and/or operations through improvements to plant and/or procedures.  Any such opportunity will be properly evaluated and managed through the site's management of change procedure (PAL-PSM-010) prior to implementation.



OFFSITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS



An offsite consequence analysis has been prepared in accordance with the rules specified in 40 CFR 68, which require that ethylene oxide be treated as a gas liquefied by pressure.  As such, the rules require that the worst case release be the entire inve

ntory of the largest container released over a 10 minute period.  As detailed elsewhere in this RMP submission, the endpoint for this scenario is 12 miles.



This analysis is not credible, as it is thermodynamically impossible for the entire inventory of the largest tank of ethylene oxide to vaporize over 10 minutes.  Features in place that would further limit this scenario include:



- ethylene oxide tanks are kept cool such that liquid temperature range is between 50 deg.F (the boiling point of EO at atmospheric pressure) and 70 deg.F

- the tanks are contained within a dike that is adequate to contain the entire inventory of the largest tank

- tanks do not have any nozzles or connections below the liquid level



A release into the diked area will result in a liquid pool at 50 deg.F, which would vaporize over time.  This release would be similar to the propylene oxide worst case scenario, with a distance to the end point significantly lower than the 12 miles determined in accordance with the RMP rules.



Additional offsite consequence analyses addressed in this RMP are:



- Alternative release of EO, based on a release during transfer of EO from rail tanker.  Release was assumed to be stopped after 1 minute by activation of emergency shutdown devices.  Distance to end point for this scenario was calculated at 1.1 miles.



- Worst case release of PO (treated as a toxic liquid per RMP rules).  The entire contents of the PO storage tank is assumed to be released into the dike and vaporize over time.  Distance to end point for this scenario was calculated at 1.8 miles.



- Alternative release of PO, based on a release during transfer of PO from tank truck.  Release was assumed to be stopped after 1 minute by activation of emergency shutdown devices.  Distance to end point for this scenario was calculated at 0.2 miles.
